= **íåç [[[SCP-8660]]] íÅπ [[[dead king's march|Hub]]] íÅπ**

Irkalla burns.

The grave-wind howls through the stalactites of quartz and mica, that shine like stars on the ceiling of that almighty cavern, and carries with it the scent of smoke, of spilt blood and flickering flame, of red-handed war, vengeful and ascendant. 

Beneath the ground, in pale Irkalla, in the House of Dust, an army of ghosts marches along an avenue paved with skulls. 

See them, these warlike shades, wrists bearing broken manacles, banners emblazoned with a bronze axe on sable black. See them, sickle-swords at their sides, rifles slung over their shoulders, marching-hymns on their lips. From the Ashen Plains they come, from the Clay Hinterlands they come, from Gibil-Uruk and Ugal-Nineveh, from the Hanging Forests and the Screeching Deserts, these gray men and women who have broken their chains and masters, who come now to break their tyrant god.

See many such columns flow into one, an armored serpent a thousand ranks deep and fifty broad. Terrible things join them, stranger still than the marching dead. Overhead and besides, behind and underfoot, scurrying with chitinous hands, flapping with leathery wings, scuttling with many legs, whispering with choral voices, monsters redeemed and redeeming. 

See the procession crest a final hill, to overlook the //tahazu-ki//, the Killing Fields. 

And there, so very near at hand, squatting like a bloatfly upon a wound, the pale bulwark of Hulgig-Babylon, Nergal‚Äôs City of Dread, wretched capital of the House of Dust. Ten tiers of walls upon walls upon walls, rising from the bloodsoaked earth to graze the shrouded undersky, a child‚Äôs fantasy of war and fortification, crenellations and bastions and kill-zones and the gleam of dozens of portcullises, a fortress beyond mortal reckoning, even reduced. Its outer defenses are overrun, some walls reduced to slag and rubble, a wounded beast bleeding black smoke and flickering with flame, but it is the demesne of an undying god, mighty in aspect, and to see it in its totality is to know oneself as flotsam trailing in the wake of leviathans. 

But it bleeds, nonetheless. 

The procession marches along.

See the mighty war-camp that surrounds it, silken pavilions blooming around the outskirts of the fortress-city like mushrooms over carrion, outlined by traceries of fortifications and counter-fortifications, mage-towers and artillery emplacements, trenches of flame, shattered walls, and anti-aircraft cannons bristling like porcupine quills.

And still the grave-wind blows, ever overhead.


Hear that infernal chorus play, that symphony of discorporation, of twice-death, of those feathered spirits burned and rent like insects, their smoke caught by the gallows. It catches on canvas tarps, on silken pavilions, on a thousand fluttering banners of bronze on black. 

See the vanguard of the Army of the Dead enter the camp, kneeling in the dust, left hands pressed in the sign of supplication, hail, hail, hail.

And at the center of it all he is there to receive them, to affirm their oaths, to clasp their withered hands in his, to pull them out of the dust and set them to their stations.

He who is king and god and country, all in one. 


Twice-slayer of the Bull of Heaven and Hell, slayer and savior of Humbaba, slayer of demons, slayer of monsters, Slayer of Wickedness, claimant ascendant to the throne of Hell.

GILGAMESH, King-in-waiting of Irkalla, Bringer of Hope and Breaker of Chains, anointed champion of the Goddess of the Dead, íÑ§ íàó.

See him, standing at the summit of the siegeworks erected encircling Nergal‚Äôs City of Dread. See his vibrant skin of feathers and lacquer now almost as flesh, his eyes of amber vibrant and sharp, his armor of gilded steel repaired and enhanced and affixed with Irkallan bronze and engines from the Furthest West, at his side Violence glinting in the twilight, axe-head as broad as an Akkadian shield. 

He raises it now, hefts five-hundred pounds of bronze with a single mighty hand, roaring his acclamation to the stony heavens, the sound roiling like a wave, thundering over the battlefield, resounding off of the ivory walls of Hulgig-Babylon, dread and awe and bloody vengeance, vengeance come at last. 

The dead roar with him, all as one. 

-----

Now the hero-king sits in private council, in the vellum tent of Ashurbanipal the Invincible, //sukkal// to the Kingdom of Dust, who signs with many arms and sees with many eyes, who whispers in the secret dreams of Buffett and Fink and Golub, who covets much and takes much of what he covets. At his feet lie the minion-things Memory and Ledger, reedy throats endlessly intoning the Twenty Thousand Words of Power, holding in their minds of wax every word ever put to wetted clay. 

At the hero-king‚Äôs right hand sits jeweled Shamhat, bearer of the secret names of the wind, arrayed in the imperious regalia of a //harimtu// at high court, refined and fragrant and elegant, who men now call Silkworm and Spider, highest spymaster of the Kingdom of Dust, first amongst equals in counsel and wisdom and the esteem of the king. 

And at the hero-king‚Äôs left sits Staff Sergeant Jack Montague, Dead-eye, warrior and emissary from the Furthest West. 

The council begins with little ceremony, for there is much to be said.

**GILGAMESH**: Hail, brothers of my blood, hail, sister of my heart, hail, you three who are my highest councillors, exemplars of my Kingdom of Dust.

**ALL**: Hail Gilgamesh, King of the Dead, king of kings, Slayer of Wickedness, rightful ruler of Irkalla, of the House of Dust.


**GILGAMESH**: Four days ago I rode with my cuirassiers and cataphracts and chariots of wood and iron, and met with Nergal‚Äôs great sortie upon the field, and crushed it, and took the head of Ishum, the watchman, in single combat. Two days ago, counter-battery fire from our emplaced guns silenced the last of Nergal‚Äôs field artillery, and the Dead-eye‚Äôs scouts overran them, and turned them back upon the walls. Seven hours ago, our fliers met with the Host of the Furies in the undersky above the city, and broke them, and did greatly attrit the Jackal‚Äôs A3/AD bubble, in concordance with the principles of SEAD.

**MONTAGUE**: Well spoken, my lord. We have them on the ropes, that is to say, victory is near at hand. With the last of Nergal‚Äôs counteroffensives crushed, and our cordon interdicting all supplies of foodstuffs and materiel, it is only a question of starving them out. Our numbers swell every day with fresh rebels, now that our banners are raised beneath the walls of the capital itself. Hold fast, and we cannot lose.

**SHAMHAT**: That is a question of some concern, Emissary from the Furthest West. 

**MONTAGUE**: What do you mean?

**SHAMHAT**: The capital will starve, yes, without supplies of corpse-grain, and wine, and //udug//, and eventually its host will wither and fail. But Nergal has twenty-thousand //gallu// in the city, and five thousand demons of Tartarus, and five thousand Luciferean mercenaries, and a population of some seventy-thousand //ul-uzuh//, the last of his faithful. Traitors they may be, and of the highest order besides, but if the capital starves the //gallu// and demons will seize upon them like ripe fruit, and slaughter them to a man for sustenance.

**GILGAMESH**: That cannot be. I will not allow it.

**MONTAGUE**: My lord, a frontal assault on the walls of Hulgig-Babylon may cost us everything! Their host is still mighty, and Nergal himself is yet unseen, at the height of his strength. If we make a run at the walls, the Jackal will make his move. It may be that he will seek to kill you himself, my lord, and should you fall, all will be for naught. That is an unacceptable level of risk to take up over the lives of traitors-

**GILGAMESH**: Enough! Traitors they may be, Dead-eye, but they are brothers of my land all the same! Or have you forgotten the oath I swore upon the names of the gods and the faces of the sun and moon, to consign no more of my brethren to twice-death than absolutely necessary? By action or inaction both, Dead-eye! The course you speak of is massacre. I will entertain it no further. Risk is the necessary burden of kingship.

**MONTAGUE**: I apologize, Lord Gilgamesh.

**GILGAMESH**: It is forgiven. Ashurbanipal, foremost of my mages, I turn to you now. Have you any workings which may level the blasted walls of this place? Any sorcery which would aid in our assault?

**ASHURBANIPAL**: I have many, my lord. However-

**MEMORY**: //And he shall hold twice again the grain in reserve, to weather the famine, and give unto the tax-collector-//

**ASHURBANIPAL**: Quiet, you. But yes, therein lies the issue. For though I am mighty, and suzerain, and my will is invincible, breaching the walls of Hulgig-Babylon of my sole accord would leave me utterly spent. And then Nergal would seize upon us, and rend us to ash, for I must keep three-fourths of my strength in reserve at all times, to defend against such a stroke. I cannot level the walls alone, my lord.

The council breaks into contention then, while the hero-king sits on his simple seat of clay, and closes his eyes in contemplation, for a time. When he opens them again they are bright, and his smile is feral and wild, and the beating of his heart of clay echoes throughout the room like thunder.

**GILGAMESH**: You cannot level the walls alone, you say? And well said, for a sling is useless without a stone, and a bowman useless without his arrows.

**ASHURBANIPAL**: What is your meaning, my lord?

**GILGAMESH**: Hear me, councillors to my Kingdom of Dust! Our plan is as it will ever be. //Violence of action.//

------

= **September, 1982**

A single Bell UH-1 Huey screams through the frigid night. No escorts this time. If everything goes according to plan, we won‚Äôt need ‚Äòem. If not, well, it‚Äôd just be wasting lives.

The king occupies his half of the chopper with poise and grace. He‚Äôs meditating, hands clasped. I wonder if he‚Äôs praying, and to whom? We‚Äôve strapped his axe, that fridge-sized hunk of bronze called //Violence//, to the side of the airframe, and the pilot is countering the added weight admirably. She‚Äôs stoic, keeping us level no matter how much her stick yearns to veer left. In any other unit in the world, we would‚Äôve needed to draw lots to figure out who would be forced to go on a mission like this. But in the King‚Äôs army, we had to pick from a dozen volunteers, all eager to ferry our leader to his final battle. She had seniority, go figure.

I glance at the other passenger on my side. Ashurbanipal, trusted //sukkal// of the King of the Dead. After I finished my degree, I went years without thinking of him as anything other than a footnote in history; now he‚Äôs two seats over. I don‚Äôt like making eye contact with Ash, but it‚Äôs hard not to: he‚Äôs got eyes on the back of his head, and on six of his palms, and a dozen more tracing swift orbits around his torso. I think he notices the discomfort, relishes it. A man doesn‚Äôt become like //that// unless he really relishes it. 

The Huey lurches, my hands straining against the straps. The monstrous shape of Hulgig-Babylon looms larger and larger in the windscreen, and this close it seems even the winds bow to the tyrant, Nergal. Not for long. 

The radio crackles. Tailwards, on a distant hill, Pentagram warfighters have assembled eight PM198 towed heavy howitzers loaded with CAIN rounds. Rugged, sexy machines, each capable of launching a hundred-fifty pounds of sanctified steel at supersonic speeds to hit a target the size of a basketball from fifteen miles away. I‚Äôm almost sad I‚Äôm not there to watch the enfilade, but this view is still to die for. The silent signal goes out, and the grand guns open fire in one unified volley, the resounding //boom// echoing in the corrugated valleys of Irkalla. Eight warheads streak over our rotors almost too close for comfort, trajectories aligning on a single point dead ahead.

They strike the grim walls of Hulgig-Babylon simultaneously, sending shockwaves resounding through the structure as cracks spiderweb around the impact crater and outlying walls shatter. It‚Äôs not enough to break through a dozen layers of enchanted obsidian brick, but it doesn‚Äôt have to be. The structure comes alive like a beehive, fires alighting in every nook and cranny as the Nergalites ready for the assault. Scores of winged //gallu// drop from balconies and scream towards our rotors. They‚Äôre willing to dash themselves in our blades, if it‚Äôll stop our approach. From a thousand embrasures, many-armed archers launch arrows tipped with red-hot ceramic vessels. It‚Äôs a Nergalite solution to anti-air, and unfortunately more effective than you‚Äôd think. The marrow-ooze inside sticks like tar and can melt through an engine block in fifteen seconds. We‚Äôve lost two Hueys in as many weeks to the damn things, and nearly a dozen fliers.

The king shifts, imperceptible to the eye, but when his attention coalesces you //feel// it in your gut. He gives Ashurbanipal a nod. I‚Äôve never seen another man who could convey this much meaning with a single tilt of the head.

The dead archmage begins to chant. His many arms spin around him as if to stabilize a wild gyroscope, picking up speed. At first I can‚Äôt keep track of what language he‚Äôs using, and then I realize it‚Äôs more than that; I count at least four languages, three pantheons, and two contradictory systems of magic spilling from that man‚Äôs parchment lips. It‚Äôs like a song, all the dead wolves of Yellowstone crying out at once, whale-calls and birdsong in a symphony of extinction. They cry for vengeance, and the universe twists to fulfill them.

In the space around our chopper, six skeletal limbs unfurl, bones thick as tree trunks, splayed out in a lotus. They‚Äôre adorned with spectral bracelets, rings and bangles, mirroring Ashurbanipal‚Äôs own, and when he moves his many arms they mimic him perfectly. He opens his eyes, all of them, all at once, and the air reeks of ozone.

From starboard, a shrieking flock of winged //gallu// dive at the windows, the massive limbs swatting them aside like flies, tearing through the swarm in clouds of pink mist. Splattered harpy blood paints the side of the Huey, but we keep flying, windshield wipers smearing gore over the cockpit windows. Impossibly fast, the arms whip back to block a barrage of acid-tipped arrows from 12-o-clock, corrosion fizzling against enchanted bone. From port, a Jersey Devil swoops, a mess of hooves and leathery wings, emitting a blood-curdling cry so harsh it makes the windows shake. Inside the chopper, Ashurbanipal reaches forward, grasping empty space, and closes his hand into a fist. The noise stops. 

Ahead of us, the crater in the wall looms closer. Our pilot bears forward full tilt. Ash gathers his arms, and they each brace, forming a barrier of spectral bone at the craft‚Äôs nose. I brace against the hull. Gilgamesh hardly moves.

We make impact. 

-----

= íÄ≠íÄ≠íÄ≠íÄ≠

The sky-chariot, cradled in the arms of Ashurbanipal the Invincible, pierces through the weakened barricades of Hulgig-Babylon as an arrow pierces soft flesh. It emerges into a twilit void, the hollow interior of Nergal‚Äôs grim capital, and its round wings beat upon an eerie silence. The crooked streets lined with clay hovels and obsidian battlements are devoid of movement and unlife, baskets of goods scattered about the ground, market-stalls empty but with braziers still alight.


The sky-charioteer guides the machine to alight upon the rough stones of the City of Dread and its mechanical heart murmurs as its wings slow to a stop. And then there is silence, as Ashurbanipal‚Äôs phantom limbs become one with the dust of the street, mingling with the scraps of slain spirits that litter the gutters.

See the hero-king dismount, hear his sandaled feet striking the cobblestones. With his eyes of lacquer he surveys the city, the seat of Irkalla‚Äôs rule, wretched crown of the Netherworld, now still and rigid as a corpse. His companions follow in his steps.

**MONTAGUE:** I do not understand. The guards have left their posts, to the last man. Look, see their weapons lying in the dust. Has Nergal abandoned the defense of his city?

**GILGAMESH:** I think not. Listen, friends, to the grave-wind. If you allow it to fill you, you may distinguish the clamor of crowds, the jeers of an audience, and the tense air of anticipation.

**ASHURBANIPAL:** I hear it, my lord. The jackal-god has prepared for us, as we have for him. He would have you settle things in the oldest way, a test of champions. As we foresaw. Are you ready?

**GILGAMESH:** No man is ever truly ready to fight a god. But I am ready to do what is necessary for my people. I will always be ready.

**MONTAGUE:** There is no man alive or dead more worthy than you, my king.

And so the retinue of the dead-king marches to the place of endings.

In the center of Hulgig-Babylon is an arena, built brick by brick by Nergal‚Äôs own hands, hewn from marble quarried by the god himself, raised over the course of centuries by divine will and nestled within the heart of the wretched city. It does not bear the marks of Irkalla‚Äôs masonry, it does not bear the foundation-pegs inscribed with the name of Irnina, the goddess of victory. It does not bear flowing inscriptions of Sumerian, Akkadian, or Arabic, but instead the bare, rigid script of Rome, and of America, of the Furthest West. The sweeping buttresses of marble, the facade open to the void, the circular arena, foreign to behold, presenting as a pale cyst upon the face of that darkling, hollow city. 

Gilgamesh, king of kings, strides through the entryway into the bloodied sand of the Colosseum of Nergal to resounding cheers and the stamping of feet. 

The hopeful dead of Irkalla fill the rows of that colossal space in their thousands, and more besides. The rows between are filled by the //gallu// soldiers and demon mercenaries of Nergal‚Äôs army, and winged beasts swoop overhead in the rafters, jockeying for space. The eyes of all Irkalla bear down upon the First Hero, each seeking a different turn of victory, and he must deliver. 

Look, but shield your eyes: seated upon the balcony is Nergal glad-of-war, red-hand, jackal-god, lord of inflicted death and tyrant-god of Irkalla. He is a thing of shining black chitin, a beetle‚Äôs shell fashioned into the shape of a muscled man, a head taller than even the king. His smile stretches wider than his face, his teeth sharpened to bloodied points, and his crown is a circlet of steel and fire. His seat is the Throne of Ereshkigal, the once-blessed focus of her dominion, from which she ruled with compassion and justice until sundered by basest treachery. It is more than a throne, that seat of chalcedony and amethyst, it is divinity incarnate, woven power, the //me// of the God of the Dead.

**NERGAL:**  [[span style="font-family:'Slabo 13px', serif;font-size: 16px;"]]Welcome, beloved guests! Oh, once-king of Uruk, you are twofold as majestic as the poets sing![[/span]]

**GILGAMESH:** Silence, jackal-god. Your end has come. I will grant you one measure of respect for confining our fatal struggle to this arena, but speak no more jests at this hour, lest you be taken for a cur.

**NERGAL:** [[span style="font-family:'Slabo 13px', serif;font-size: 16px;"]]Dearest Gilgamesh, you fail to understand. I do not jest. My heart fills with joy to see you and your retinue come to meet me at last. I have followed your rebellion with rapt interest and admiration, and I have come to respect you all, truly, as friends, and indeed, as worshippers most adept.[[/span]]

**NERGAL:** [[span style="font-family:'Slabo 13px', serif;font-size: 16px;"]]You, representative of the United States of America. Know that  I favor your homeland above all the nations of the living. In ages past, I would have granted boons in great proportion to spur a nation of such strength to grind its young in the mortar of war forevermore, but your leaders do so without bribe nor divine encouragement. Your struggles are delightful.[[/span]]

**MONTAGUE:** You assume much of which you do not know, Jackal. I will gladly lay down my arms when the cause is done. We stand here as liberators.


**NERGAL:** [[span style="font-family:'Slabo 13px', serif;font-size: 16px;"]]Liberators! We shall see, American. And you, Ashurbanipal the Invincible, known to the Hebrews as Nebuchadnezzar, know that I speak truly when I say: long have I admired you and your deeds, in life as well as death. Scarce in all the annals of  history has a king done me greater honor than you.  You slaughtered the Elamites nearly to the last child to slake the bloodlust of your people and prolong your reign, measuring their lives as grains of wheat upon your scales. You sieged Babylon and set it alight with your brother still inside. How many cities did you burn solely to sack their libraries for ritual texts?[[/span]]

**ASHURBANIPAL:** I lived on Earth the way I chose, and used my time and means as I saw fit. For that I will not apologize.

**NERGAL:**  [[span style="font-family:'Slabo 13px', serif;font-size: 16px;"]]Nor should you, great scholar of murder! I have not forgotten how you burnt offerings to me before each battle, animal as well as man. How you rebuilt my great temple, E-Meslam, and reconsecrated it in my  name. I remember your offering, breathing my hundred names as you drove the silvered dagger through the heart of your mistress. I remember how you promised everything to me, if I would only give you power. Tell me, //sukkal//,  are you happy with your choice?[[/span]]

**ASHURBANIPAL:** I regret nothing.

**NERGAL:** [[span style="font-family:'Slabo 13px', serif;font-size: 16px;"]]Of course, of course!  I so love to please a believer. But now you turn on me, pretend as though you never revered me. Do not lie to yourself, Ashurbanipal.  I know the faith still burns in your heart.[[/span]]

**ASHURBANIPAL:** I sought your power in life because it suited my goals, and now I seek your destruction for the same reason. You are now as you have always been: subordinate to my interests.

**GILGAMESH:** Cease this chatter. Great Destroyer, He Who Has Come Out of Meslam. I am GILGAMESH, two-parts god and one-part man. I have been anointed by Ereshkigal, rightful ruler of Irkalla, and she has granted me leave to take her throne back from you, wretched pretender. I challenge you to a test of strength for your throne, by the most ancient compact of men and gods. Wrestle me, as I wrestled the Bull of Heaven, so I may take your throne from you. Wrestle me, so that I may tear your crooked crown from your crooked brow and show to all powers, living and dead, mortal and godly, the false king that you truly are, that I may spill your tyrant‚Äôs blood and wring your traitor‚Äôs entrails!

Oh listen how Nergal laughs so! Listen as the halls of the arena are filled with the whistle-wind laughter of the Lord of Poplars! Hear the creaking of his throne as he leans to gaze down upon Gilgamesh, the fires of war shining in his insect-eyes like rusted coins at a dry well's bottom.

**NERGAL:** [[span style="font-family:'Slabo 13px', serif;font-size: 16px;"]]Oh, mighty Gilgamesh, are you still yet to see? Has no-one informed their king of the truth? Perhaps none remember. Listen, and listen well, to the truth I now bestow.  It has been many ages since I have been challenged in this manner. Indeed, yours is not the first rebellion to rally all Irkalla against me. Oh, there was once a leader like you, your equal in strength and courage. A wild-man was he, and he did challenge me to a wrestling match as well, to tame me and my savage ways, he said, to reform me as he did for you.[[/span]]

**GILGAMESH:** You speak of my other half. You speak of the friend who was taken from me. You speak of Enkidu. Where is he? What have you done to him?

**NERGAL:** [[span style="font-family:'Slabo 13px', serif;font-size: 16px;"]]I bested him, Gilgamesh. I forced his face into the sand and I made him yield, made him plead for mercy. Then, I ate of him. I rended him as a child would an insect, and I ate of him. I crushed his soul between my basalt teeth and I made him less than dust. For I knew, great Gilgamesh, that he was most loved by you. I knew that you would fall into the House of Dust as willful as you were in life, and mighty in spirit, that you would reject my yoke, and break my chains. I knew that you would raise a rebellion and bring war to Irkalla once more, and bring new purpose to my eternity. And I knew, oh first hero, that when you learned of your love‚Äôs twice-death, as you have now, your fury will be as such that no poet can describe. Come, come, give me a contest worthy of the God of War! Come, First Hero, now knowing the truth of my deeds, I am here, I am waiting![[/span]]

Gilgamesh is still, then, as still as stone, as stoic as the cavern-walls of marble that encircle Irkalla, as still as the firmament of the undersky above, and his dimmed eyes are dusty with the dry tears of the dead. Oh hear his voice, hear it tremble as his cobwebbed beard trembles, gutter as the torches gutter, as he pronounces his final challenge, his voice heavy with the sorrow of five thousand years of longing, as his gilded armor whirs and roars with sympathetic fury.

**GILGAMESH:** Hear me well, Jackal. I will kill you as one kills a rabid dog that bites its master's hand. You, Drought King of the Summer Solstice, are to die on this day by these red-soaked hands of mine. You, Lord of Misrule and Mars, shall answer for your crimes against the living and the dead, for your wars, your pestilences, your droughts and famines. You will answer for the desecration of my great city of Uruk, and for the twice-death of my lover Enkidu, and for your cruelty and your tyranny and the million voices you have cast into the grave-wind. For this and more I will have you grovel at my feet and kiss the soles of my sandals. It shall be you who is made less than dust, and I shall scatter your ashes before the widows you have created and the orphans you have sired so that they may know peace, so that the land may know peace by your passing, and the country may be made whole by your absence. This I swear upon the faces of the sun and moon, upon the names of all the gods. Enough talk, wretch. 

With this, Nergal rises from his stolen throne. He stands, naked and unadorned, his skin like the shells of carrion beetles that crawl over the dead after a battle, a shining lacquered black glistening with sacred oils and unguents. See the jackal-god‚Äôs eyes, shining like rusted coins at a dry well's bottom. See the glad-of-war descend his dais of broken crowns, see the red-hand jump from his balcony and land in the arena sands to look upon the hero-king from level ground. See our hero raise a mighty fist to wipe away his tears of dust. 

See the war-god smile.
